quizzes.question: Of what type are the :link, :visited, :active and :hover selectors?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Setting Styles to Links[/h1] Links can be styled with any CSS property (e.g., color, font-family, background, etc.). In addition, links can be styled differently, depending on what state they are in. The following pseudo selectors are available: [b]a:link[/b] - defines the style for normal unvisited links [b]a:visited[/b] - defines the style for visited links [b]a:active[/b] - a link becomes active once you click on it [b]a:hover[/b] - a link is hovered when the mouse is over it The example below creates a link that will change the style when the mouse is moved over it. [b]The HTML:[/b][code format="html" ]

This link is hovered when we mouse over it

[/code] [b] The CSS:[/b][code format="css" codeId="560"][b]a:hover [/b]{ color: red; } [/code] The link from the above example would look like this: [img id="2641" width="100%"] But when we mouse over it, it becomes red, as we defined in our stylesheet. [img id="2642" width="100%"] [note]When setting the style for several link states, there are some order rules: - a:hover MUST come after a:link and a:visited - a:active MUST come after a:hover[/note]

quizzes.question: What value is used to remove borders of images with links?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Links' Text Decoration[/h1] By default, text links are underlined by the browser. One of the most common uses of CSS with links is to [b]remove the underline[/b]. In the example below, the [b]text-decoration[/b] property is used to remove the underline. [b]The HTML:[/b] [code format="html" ]

This link has no underline.

[/code] [b]The CSS:[/b] [code format="css" codeId="561"]a:link { [b]text-decoration: none;[/b] }[/code] [b]Result:[/b] [img id="2643" width="100%"] [note]The following properties are used to control the look and feel of links: [b]border:none[/b] - removes border from images with links [b]outline:none[/b] - removes the dotted border on clicked lines in IE[/note]
